Idioms.phrase: A fool and his money are soon parted
Idioms.definition: Which means, a foolish person is very likely to lose his money.
Which means, a state of euphoria with no basis in reality.
Which means, an initial inroad that may lead to greater influence in future.

Idioms.phrase: A golden key can open any door
Idioms.definition: Which means, money always has a telling influence.
Which means, a current issue which many people are talking about and which is controversial.

Idioms.phrase: A house divided against itself cannot stand
Idioms.definition: Which means, failure is certain if those on the same side argue amongst themselves.
Which means, a person who comes to the aid of another when other hopes have faded, like the knights in romantic stories.

Idioms.phrase: A leopard can't change his spots
Idioms.definition: Which means, you cannot change your innate self.
Which means, i was told by an undisclosed source.
Which means, nonsense.

Which means, having many responsibilities.

Idioms.phrase: A man after my own heart
Idioms.definition: Which means, a kindred spirit. Someone who thinks as I do.

Idioms.definition: Which means, some endeavours either succeed or they donât - to miss narrowly is still failure.
Which means, a way of asking what someone is thinking.

Idioms.phrase: A penny saved is a penny earned
Idioms.definition: Which means, anything you save has the same effect as adding to your income.

Idioms.phrase: A picture paints a thousand words
Idioms.definition: Which means, pictures are far more descriptive than words.
Which means, a task that can be accomplished very easily.
Which means, a commodity that is bought without first examining it.

Which means, a mild rebuke, often given when a more severe punishment might be expected.

Idioms.definition: Which means, the use of excessive resources to overcome a small problem.
Which means, 1. Something sadly neglected. 2. A person or thing of untidy appearance.

Idioms.phrase: A stitch in time saves nine
Idioms.definition: Which means, a small effort made at the right time might save a calamity later on.
Which means, a short distance.

Idioms.phrase: A taste of your own medicine
Idioms.definition: Which means, mistreatment you receive in retaliation to that you gave to others.
Which means, a persistent and difficult to ignore annoyance.
Which means, 1. The flip of a coin to decide on something. 2. A result, usually between two courses of action, which is uncertain and could go either way.
Which means, someone who uses the pretence of kindliness to disguise their evil intent.
Which means, 1. A military command to turn when on parade. 2. A change from oneâs previous position.
Which means, 1. Almost time. 2. High time.

Idioms.definition: Which means, our feelings for people and things grows when we are apart from them.

Which means, a saved, hidden advantage that can supply a victory when revealed.
Which means, a fatal weakness in an otherwise strong person or thing.
Which means, applying everywhere and to all classes of thing.
Which means, behave in a manner appropriate to your stage in life.
Which means, actions show oneâs character more than what you say.
Which means, a reference to water - often used to emphasize the purity of water compared to other drinks.
Which means, make a bad situation even worse than it is.
Which means, to further a loss. To make a bad situation worse.
Which means, in a great hurry to complete something before a set deadline.
Which means, said by someone who has experience of a situation.
Which means, in the open air.
Which means, eating oneâs lunch while still working. (A Pun on âAl frescoâ.).

Which means, on the whole - when everything is considered.
Which means, typical; a normal set of circumstances.
Which means, ready to go.
Which means, referring to something that is done fully, especially as a euphemism for full sexual activity.

Which means, ruined or shambolic.
Which means, invitation to join in communal singing.
Which means, 1. A cat that lives wild in a town. 2. Slang term for a prostitute.

Which means, a jumble of words or letters, often referring to organisations known by their initials, like CIA or BBC.
Which means, a slang term for lager.
Which means, excited and ready for action.
Which means, some event that is considered to be outside human control. Commonly used in insurance policies to refer to events that the insured cannot be held responsible for.
Which means, very expensive. A large amount of money.
Which means, a dispute with someone.
Which means, a straightforward legal case in which the outcome is clear.
Which means, a slang term for small child.

Idioms.definition: Which means, with no delay.
Which means, not facing reality; in a dream world.
Which means, confusion or forgetfulness caused by lack of sleep when caring for a new-born.
Which means, the protruding belly of a pregnant woman. Also used to describe the unborn child itself.

Idioms.phrase: Be glad to see the back of
Idioms.definition: Which means, be happy when a person leaves or when an unpleasant situation is ended.

Idioms.phrase: Between a rock and a hard place
Idioms.definition: Which means, between two unwelcome options.

Which means, to be so prized and valuable as to not be obtainable by money.

Idioms.phrase: Big fish in a small pond
Idioms.definition: Which means, an important person but only so within a small area of influence.
